#One of the check for Logistic regression is independent variables should be independent of each other
#As I mentioned earlier, after my research i found out that, PI(Pelvic Incidence)= pelvic_tilt(PT) + sacral_slope(SS)
#Due to this reason,I have dropped the pelvic_tilt numeric and sacral_slope attributes of teh data set.
sns.scatterplot(x='pelvic_incidence',y=lba['pelvic_tilt numeric']+lba['sacral_slope'],data=lba)

#also PR is used in calculating the lumbar_lordosis_angle. 
#This leaves us with degree of degree_spondylolisthesis attribute, it seems like it is being used in classification of spine as Abnormal or Normal

source.43fe2776:
X4=lba[['pelvic_incidence', 'pelvic_tilt numeric', 'lumbar_lordosis_angle',
       'sacral_slope', 'pelvic_radius', 'degree_spondylolisthesis']]

#Creating instance of LogRegression and fittign the model
logmodel4 = LogisticRegression()
logmodel4.fit(X4_train,y_train4)
source.e664b7c6:
Data speaks volumes, the more you understand the data and context around it, we can see patterns which are hiding and will help us in enabling a better solution or prediction. In LogisticRegression, we looks for these below mentioned characteristics.

1.Dataset should have atleast  100 or more observations.

2.Dataset is not missing any values.

3.Predictable variable is binary(In this case class attribute -  0 or 1 )

4.All Predictors variables are independent of each other and variables should be continous.(The range of values for a particular data item has a minimum and a maximum value. Continuous data can be any value in between.. ex- degree of spondylolisthesis..)

 Because if they are not, it can skew the predictions/results.

After a lot of research, on the dataset,it seems Pelvic Incidence can be a good predicting variable for classifying a Normal vs abnormal spine and so is Degree Spondylitis can be another predictor variable for classifying a Normal vs abnormal spine.The relation between predictable variable and predictor variables shows #seaborn#plot sigmoid curve.Notes:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2852036/

Pelvic radius is another technique to predict the abnormalities. After some digging around, I felt like this dataset could be incomplete with r.t. Pelvic radius, we need another attributes like hip angle, pelvic angle.Here is article that I used to come to that conclusion. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3175929/

I am thankful that this dataset gave me a chance to analyze more and figure out something that I didn’t have a clue before. I am not a medical student or related to medical field. So please understand these are my observations made on my own. 

Conclusion is  Degree Spondylitis is giving better classification results (81%) to Pelvic Incidence(PI) . This dataset is definitely missing some important attributes but gave  lot of insights into the problem and how to go about it.
